sections.title: What is Gomoku?
sections.content:
Gomoku (五目並べ, five points) - also called Connect5, Five in a Row, or Gobang.

**The Board**: 15×15 grid
**The Goal**: Get 5 stones in a row (any direction)
**The Complexity**: Harder than it looks!

**Two Variants**:

**Freestyle Gomoku**: No restrictions, pure tactics
**Renju** (連珠): Black has forbidden moves (prevents guaranteed wins)

**Why Gomoku is Brilliant**:
• Simple rules anyone can learn in 30 seconds
• Deep strategy takes years to master
• Perfect information game (no luck!)
• Black has first-move advantage (hence Renju rules)

**History**:
• Originated in China (same roots as Go)
• Popular in Japan (五目並べ)
• Competitive tournaments worldwide
• Solved for some board sizes (Black wins with perfect play on 15×15 freestyle!)

sections.title: Rules - It's Simple!
sections.content:
**The Rules**:

1. Black plays first
2. Players alternate placing stones
3. Stones placed on intersections
4. Stones cannot be moved once placed
5. First to get 5 in a row wins!

**Directions that count**:
• Horizontal (—)
• Vertical (|)
• Diagonal (/ or \)

**Important**:
• Exactly 5 wins (not 6+)
• In Renju: 6+ in a row = overline = loses for Black!

**No Captures**: Unlike Go, stones stay on board

**Draw**: Extremely rare (full board with no winner)

sections.title: Renju - Tournament Rules
sections.content:
**Why Renju Exists**:

Black (first player) has huge advantage in freestyle Gomoku. With perfect play, Black always wins!

So tournament rules (Renju) add restrictions:

**Forbidden Moves for Black**:

1. **Double Three**: Creating two open 3-in-a-rows simultaneously = forbidden
2. **Double Four**: Creating two open 4-in-a-rows = forbidden
3. **Overline**: 6+ in a row = loses immediately!

**White has NO restrictions** - can make any move

**Why This Works**:
Balances the game! Now it's nearly even.
Top-level Renju is incredibly sophisticated.

**Tournament Standard**:
All serious Gomoku/Renju competitions use these rules.

**For Beginners**: Play freestyle first, learn Renju later!

sections.title: Tactical Patterns
sections.content:
**VCT - Victory by Continuous Threats**:

Create threats faster than opponent can respond.

**How it works**:
1. Create double threat (two 3-in-a-rows)
2. Opponent blocks one
3. You create another double threat
4. Repeat until you win!

**VCF - Victory by Continuous Fours**:

Even more powerful! Every move is a 4-in-a-row.

**How it works**:
1. Create open 4-in-a-row
2. Opponent MUST block
3. Your block creates another 4
4. Forced win sequence!

**Key Concepts**:

**Open Three** (○○○__): Can become 4 on either end
**Closed Three** (X○○○_): Only one end can extend
**Open Four** (_○○○○_): Guaranteed win next move!
**Closed Four** (X○○○○_): Can still win

**Defensive Priority**:
1. Block opponent's open four (or you lose!)
2. Block opponent's double three
3. Block opponent's open three
4. Create your own threats

sections.title: Winning Strategy
sections.content:
**Opening Principles**:

• First move: Usually center (H8) or near-center
• Spread out early (don't cluster)
• Build multiple threats simultaneously
• Control key intersections

**Middle Game**:

• Create forks (two threats at once)
• Force opponent to defend
• Build toward VCT or VCF
• Watch for opponent's threats!

**Pattern Recognition**:

**Strong Patterns**:
• Diagonal lines are powerful
• L-shapes create multiple threats
• Cross patterns are hard to defend

**Weak Patterns**:
• Straight lines are easy to block
• Clumped stones waste potential
• Edge play limits options

**Famous Saying**: 
"In Gomoku, every move is both offense and defense!"

**Advanced Concept - Tempo**:
• Who has the initiative?
• Creating threats = gaining tempo
• Responding to threats = losing tempo
• Win by keeping tempo until VCT/VCF

**For Beginners**:
1. Always look for opponent's open 4s!
2. Create multiple 3s simultaneously
3. Think 2-3 moves ahead
4. Practice, practice, practice!
